speak;Morrissey;Ah, young Simon.
speak;Morrissey;I haven't seen you since you were a child, if my memory serves me.
speak;Morrissey;What brings you here?
s;Simon;Lord Morrissey, I'm hoping to restore our houses' alliance.
s;Simon;I know you were close with my father, but the uprisings and monsters....{w}{br}They made it hard to visit as often as I'd like after his passing.
s;Morrissey;I see...
s;Morrissey;Yes, with the so-called "New Dawn's" wanton destruction of the area,{w}{br}it makes sense that House Verstadt was preoccupied.
s;Morrissey;I'm more than happy to rebuild our houses' relationship.
s;Morrissey;But I must ask, why now?
s;Morrissey;The monsters and rebels have only become more of an issue.
s;Morrissey;I hate to pry, but something must have prompted you to come here.
s;Simon;You're right, of course.
s;Simon;Well, part of this is because I... {w}need your help.
s;Simon;House Verstadt has fallen.
s;Morrissey;Surely not...
s;Morrissey;To what?
s;Simon;Those "New Dawn" thugs. {w}They attacked us at night.
s;Simon;Their forces are much stronger than we expected...
s;Morrissey;I see...
s;Simon;The noble houses are in danger, Lord Morrissey.
s;Simon;Few houses remain, especially East of the capital.
s;Simon;And with the route to the capital held by New Dawn, we're cut off from the rest of the region.
s;Morrissey;I agree that this is quite dire.
s;Morrissey;This is all quite a shame... the nobles' might has never been challenged to such a degree.
s;Morrissey;I am open to negotiating on this.
s;Morrissey;And I do not mean to sound unwilling to help,{w}{br}we must stand together in times like these, after all.
s;Morrisset;Yet, I cannot afford to spare troops now, with the area in such disarray.
s;Morrissey;But we'll speak more tomorrow. It grows late.
s;Morrissey;You are welcome to stay here for the night.
speak;Morrissey;I will have my servants prepare chambers for you and your retainers.
speak;Simon;... Thank you, sir.
